what: Creating datasets with identical summary statistics
title: An overview of anscombiser
text: datasauRus package (Locke D’Agostino McGowan (2018)) provides examples datasets markedly different scatter plots nevertheless share many sample summary statistics. datasets produced using simulated annealing algorithm seeks morph incrementally initial dataset towards target shape maintaining sample summary statistics (Matejka Fitzmaurice (2017)). principle, set summary statistics can used. Indeed, Locke D’Agostino McGowan (2018) provides datasets values Anscombe’s statistics (essentially sample means, variances correlation) also datasets constrained share sample median, interquartile range Spearman’s rank correlation. anscombiser package takes simpler quicker approach problem, using Anscombe’s statistics. uses shifting, scaling rotating transform observations input dataset achieve target set Anscombe’s statistics. statistics can set directly calculating target dataset, perhaps one Anscombe’s quartet. input dataset statistics similar target statistics output dataset look rather similar input dataset. Otherwise, output dataset squashed /rotated version input dataset, general shape input dataset still visible. like viewing input dataset different perspective. Thus, can easily create many datasets different general natures share values Anscombe’s statistics. addition, method works two dimensions.
code: library(anscombiser)

previous_headings: Creating datasets with identical summary statistics
title: An overview of anscombiser
text: anscombise() function takes input two-dimensional dataset outputs dataset shares Anscombe’s statistics quartet datasets. argument chooses Anscombe’s datasets use. default = 1. course, affects output dataset minimally matters want plot input dataset, example . anscombiser packages provides 8 input files: input1 input8 can used create Anscombe-like datasets, sample size 11 original Anscombe quartet. following example uses input data arranged edge circle.  Now transform Old Faithful Geyser data shares sample summary statistics Anscombe quartet.   view plot outline coast Italy strange angle resulting dataset sample summary statistics .
code: a2 <- anscombise(input2, which = 4) plot(a2) new_faithful <- anscombise(datasets::faithful, which = 4) plot(new_faithful) plot(new_faithful, input = TRUE) italy <- mapdata("Italy") new_italy <- anscombise(italy, which = 4) plot(new_italy)

previous_headings: Creating datasets with identical summary statistics
title: An overview of anscombiser
text: mimic() function anscombiser package transforms input dataset, outlined , mimic another dataset, sense replicating values Anscombe’s statistics. particularly effective feature datasauRus package dataset draws picture dinosaur. , show plot outline coast UK needs little adjustment replicate sample summary statistics dinosaur dataset.   finish section another example involving dinosaur.   final image created Accentaur Noun Project.
code: library(datasauRus) #> Warning: package 'datasauRus' was built under R version 4.5.2 library(maps) #> Warning: package 'maps' was built under R version 4.5.2 dino <- datasaurus_dozen_wide[, c("dino_x", "dino_y")] UK <- mapdata("UK") new_UK <- mimic(UK, dino) plot(new_UK, legend_args = list(x = "right")) plot(new_UK, input = TRUE, legend_args = list(x = "topright")) new_dino <- mimic(dino, trump) plot(new_dino, legend_args = list(x = "topright")) plot(new_dino, input = TRUE, legend_args = list(x = "bottomright"), pch = 20)

previous_headings: Creating datasets with identical summary statistics
title: An overview of anscombiser
text: conclude brief 3D example, using randu trees datasets datasets package.   well-known three-dimensional displays randu data non-random structure evident, isn’t evident pairwise displays.
code: new_randu <- mimic(datasets::randu, datasets::trees) # new_randu and trees share the same sample summary statistics new_randu_stats <- get_stats(new_randu) trees_stats <- get_stats(datasets::trees) # For example trees_stats$correlation #>            Girth    Height    Volume #> Girth  1.0000000 0.5192801 0.9671194 #> Height 0.5192801 1.0000000 0.5982497 #> Volume 0.9671194 0.5982497 1.0000000 new_randu_stats$correlation #>           new1      new2      new3 #> new1 1.0000000 0.5192801 0.9671194 #> new2 0.5192801 1.0000000 0.5982497 #> new3 0.9671194 0.5982497 1.0000000 pairs(trees) pairs(new_randu)

title: Authors and Citation
text: Paul J. Northrop. Author, maintainer, copyright holder.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Northrop PJ (2026). anscombiser: Create Datasets Identical Summary Statistics. R package version 1.1.0, https://paulnorthrop.github.io/anscombiser/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {anscombiser: Create Datasets with Identical Summary Statistics},   author = {Paul J. Northrop},   year = {2026},   note = {R package version 1.1.0},   url = {https://paulnorthrop.github.io/anscombiser/}, }

title: Create Datasets with Identical Summary Statistics
text: Anscombe’s quartet set four two-variable datasets several common summary statistics (essentially means, variances correlation) different joint distributions. becomes apparent data plotted, illustrates importance using graphical displays Statistics. anscombiser package provides quick easy way create several datasets common values Anscombe’s summary statistics display different behaviour plotted. transforming (shifting, scaling rotating) dataset achieve target summary statistics.

title: Create Datasets with Identical Summary Statistics
text: mimic() function transforms input dataset (dino left) values Anscombe’s summary statistics another dataset (trump right).  example images similar summary statistics outset therefore appearance dino dataset changed little. Otherwise, first dataset deformed general shape still recognisable. rotation applied input dataset unique. function mimic (function anscombise specific Anscombe’s quartet) argument idempotent controls rotation performed. special case input dataset already desired summary statistics, using idempotent = TRUE ensures output dataset input dataset.
code: library(anscombiser) library(datasauRus) dino <- datasaurus_dozen_wide[, c("dino_x", "dino_y")] new_dino <- mimic(dino, trump) plot(new_dino, legend_args = list(x = "topright")) plot(new_dino, input = TRUE, legend_args = list(x = "bottomright"), pch = 20)

title: Create Datasets with Identical Summary Statistics
text: get current released version CRAN:
code: install.packages("anscombiser")

title: Anscombe's Quartet Separated — anscombe
text: Provides Anscombe's Quartet separate data frames.

title: Anscombe's Quartet Separated — anscombe
code: anscombe1  anscombe2  anscombe3  anscombe4

title: Anscombe's Quartet Separated — anscombe
text: datasets objects class data.frame 11 rows 2 columns.

title: Anscombe's Quartet Separated — anscombe
text: Anscombe's Quartet 'Identical' Simple Linear Regressions: datasets::anscombe datasets package. ith dataset datasets::anscombe[, c(, + 4)].

title: Anscombe's Quartet Separated — anscombe
text: Anscombe, Francis J. (1973). Graphs statistical analysis. American Statistician, 27, 17-21. doi:10.2307/2682899

what: Create new versions of Anscombe's quartet — anscombise
title: Create new versions of Anscombe's quartet — anscombise
text: Modifies dataset x shares sample summary statistics Anscombe's quartet.

title: Create new versions of Anscombe's quartet — anscombise
code: anscombise(x, which = 1, idempotent = TRUE)

title: Create new versions of Anscombe's quartet — anscombise
text: x numeric matrix data frame.  column contains observations different variable.  Missing observations allowed. integer {1, 2, 3, 4}.  Anscombe's datasets use target dataset.  Obviously, makes little difference. idempotent logical scalar. idempotent = TRUE applying anscombise one datasets Anscombe's Quartet return dataset unchanged, apart change class. idempotent = FALSE returned dataset rotated version original dataset, summary statistics. See Details.

title: Create new versions of Anscombe's quartet — anscombise
text: object class c("anscombe", "matrix", "array") plot print methods. returned dataset following summary statistics common Anscombe's quartet. sample means variable. sample variances variable. sample correlation matrix. estimated regression coefficients least squares linear regressions variable variable. target new summary statistics returned attributes old_stats new_stats chosen Anscombe's quartet dataset attribute old_data.

title: Create new versions of Anscombe's quartet — anscombise
text: input dataset x modified shifting, scaling rotating sample mean covariance matrix match Anscombe quartet. rotation based square root sample correlation matrix. idempotent = FALSE square root based Cholesky decomposition matrix, using chol. idempotent = TRUE square root based spectral decomposition matrix, using output eigen. minimal rotation square root, means input data x already exactly/approximately required summary statistics returned dataset exactly/approximately target dataset.

title: Create new versions of Anscombe's quartet — anscombise
code: # Produce Anscombe-like datasets using input1 to input8  a1 <- anscombise(input1, idempotent = FALSE) plot(a1)  a2 <- anscombise(input2) plot(a2)  a3 <- anscombise(input3, idempotent = FALSE) plot(a3)  a4 <- anscombise(input4, idempotent = FALSE) plot(a4)  a5 <- anscombise(input5, idempotent = FALSE) plot(a5)  a6 <- anscombise(input6) plot(a6)  a7 <- anscombise(input7, idempotent = FALSE) plot(a7)  a8 <- anscombise(input8, idempotent = FALSE) plot(a8)   # Old faithful to new faithful new_faithful <- anscombise(datasets::faithful, which = 4) plot(new_faithful)  # Then check that the sample summary statistics are the same plot(new_faithful, input = TRUE)   # Map of Italy got_maps <- requireNamespace("maps", quietly = TRUE) if (got_maps) {   italy <- mapdata("Italy")   new_italy <- anscombise(italy, which = 4)   plot(new_italy) }

title: Internal anscombiser functions — anscombiser-internal
text: Internal anscombiser functions

title: Internal anscombiser functions — anscombiser-internal
code: is_wholenumber(x, tol = .Machine$double.eps^0.5)  is_pos_def(x, tol = 1e-06)  minimal_rotation(x)  make_stats(x, stats, idempotent = FALSE)

title: Internal anscombiser functions — anscombiser-internal
text: functions intended called user.

what: anscombiser: Create Datasets with Identical Summary Statistics — anscombiser-package
title: anscombiser: Create Datasets with Identical Summary Statistics — anscombiser-package
text: Anscombe's quartet (Anscombe, 1973) set four two-variable datasets several common summary statistics different joint distributions. becomes apparent data plotted, illustrates importance using graphical displays Statistics.  package enables creation datasets identical marginal sample means sample variances, sample correlation, least squares regression coefficients coefficient determination.  user supplies initial dataset, shifted, scaled rotated order achieve target summary statistics.  general shape initial dataset retained. target statistics can supplied directly calculated based user-supplied dataset.

title: anscombiser: Create Datasets with Identical Summary Statistics — anscombiser-package
text: main functions anscombiser anscombise, modifies user-supplied dataset shares sample summary statistics Anscombe's quartet. mimic, modified user-supplied dataset shares sample summary statistics another user-supplied dataset. See vignette("intro--anscombiser", package = "anscombiser") overview package. functions anscombise_gif mimic_gif enable animation several datasets produced anscombise mimic, respectively.

title: anscombiser: Create Datasets with Identical Summary Statistics — anscombiser-package
text: Anscombe, F. J. (1973). Graphs Statistical Analysis. American Statistician 27 (1): 17–21. doi:10.1080/00031305.1973.10478966

title: anscombiser: Create Datasets with Identical Summary Statistics — anscombiser-package
text: Maintainer: Paul J. Northrop p.northrop@ucl.ac.uk [copyright holder]

what: Animation of several Anscombised datasets — anscombise_gif
title: Animation of several Anscombised datasets — anscombise_gif
text: Create animation show datasets share sample summary statistics Anscombe's quartet.

title: Animation of several Anscombised datasets — anscombise_gif
code: anscombise_gif(   x,   which = 1,   idempotent = TRUE,   theme_name = "classic",   ease = "cubic-in-out",   transition_length = 3,   state_length = 1,   wrap = TRUE )

title: Animation of several Anscombised datasets — anscombise_gif
text: x list input datasets.  one must suitable argument x anscombise. , idempotent Vectors provide arguments names anscombise dataset.  necessary, rep_len used replicate arguments length length(x). theme_name character scalar used set ggtheme. One "grey", "gray", "bw", "linedraw", "light", "dark", "minimal", "classic", "void" "test". ease character scalar passed ease_aes control points move transitioning one dataset next. transition_length, state_length, wrap Arguments passed transition_states.

title: Animation of several Anscombised datasets — anscombise_gif
text: object class c("gganim", "gg", "ggplot") additional attribute new_data data frame 3 variables, x, y dataset containing datasets output anscombise. returned object may displayed using typing name, e.g., anim saved GIF file using anim_save, e.g., gganimate::anim_save("anscombe.gif", anim).

title: Animation of several Anscombised datasets — anscombise_gif
text: function work packages ggplot2 gganimate must installed.

title: Animation of several Anscombised datasets — anscombise_gif
code: # Animate some Anscombe-like datasets produced using input1 to input8 x <- list(input1, input2, input3, input4, input5, input6, input7, input8) idem <- c(FALSE, TRUE, FALSE, FALSE, FALSE, TRUE, FALSE, FALSE) anim <- anscombise_gif(x, idempotent = idem)

title: Calculate Anscombe's summary statistics — get_stats
text: Calculates particular set summary statistics dataset.

title: Calculate Anscombe's summary statistics — get_stats
code: get_stats(x)

title: Calculate Anscombe's summary statistics — get_stats
text: x numeric matrix data frame least 2 columns/variables. column contains observations different variable.  Missing observations allowed.

title: Calculate Anscombe's summary statistics — get_stats

title: Modify a dataset to mimic another dataset — mimic
text: x, x2 Numeric matrices data frames.  column contains observations different variable.  Missing observations allowed. get_stats(x2) sets target summary statistics. x2 missing set_stats called d = ncol(x) additional arguments supplied via ....  can used set target summary statistics (means, variances /correlations). idempotent logical scalar. idempotent = TRUE mimic(x, x) returns x, apart change class. idempotent = FALSE returned dataset may rotated version original dataset, summary statistics. See Details. ... Additional arguments passed set_stats.

title: Modify a dataset to mimic another dataset — mimic
text: object class c("anscombe", "matrix", "array") plot print methods. returned dataset following summary statistics common x2. sample means variable. sample variances variable. sample correlation matrix. estimated regression coefficients least squares linear regressions variable variable. target new summary statistics returned attributes old_stats new_stats. x2 supplied returned attribute old_data.

title: Modify a dataset to mimic another dataset — mimic
text: input dataset x modified shifting, scaling rotating sample mean covariance matrix match target dataset x2. rotation based square root sample correlation matrix. idempotent = FALSE square root based Cholesky decomposition matrix, using chol. idempotent = TRUE square root based spectral decomposition matrix, using output eigen. minimal rotation square root, means input data x already exactly/approximately required summary statistics returned dataset exactly/approximately target dataset x2.

title: Modify a dataset to mimic another dataset — mimic
code: ### 2D examples  # The UK and a dinosaur got_maps <- requireNamespace("maps", quietly = TRUE) got_datasauRus <- requireNamespace("datasauRus", quietly = TRUE) if (got_maps && got_datasauRus) {   library(maps)   library(datasauRus)   dino <- datasaurus_dozen_wide[, c("dino_x", "dino_y")]   UK <- mapdata("UK")   new_UK <- mimic(UK, dino)   plot(new_UK) } #> Warning: package 'maps' was built under R version 4.5.2 #> Warning: package 'datasauRus' was built under R version 4.5.2   # Trump and a dinosaur if (got_datasauRus) {   library(datasauRus)   dino <- datasaurus_dozen_wide[, c("dino_x", "dino_y")]   new_dino <- mimic(dino, trump)   plot(new_dino) }   ## Examples of passing summary statistics  # The default is zero mean, unit variance and no correlation new_faithful <- mimic(faithful) plot(new_faithful)   # Change the correlation mat <- matrix(c(1, -0.9, -0.9, 1), 2, 2) new_faithful <- mimic(faithful, correlation = mat) plot(new_faithful)   ### A 3D example  new_randu <- mimic(datasets::randu, datasets::trees) # The samples summary statistics are equal get_stats(new_randu) #> $n #> [1] 400 #>  #> $means #>     new1     new2     new3  #> 13.24839 76.00000 30.17097  #>  #> $variances #>       new1       new2       new3  #>   9.847914  40.600000 270.202796  #>  #> $correlation #>           new1      new2      new3 #> new1 1.0000000 0.5192801 0.9671194 #> new2 0.5192801 1.0000000 0.5982497 #> new3 0.9671194 0.5982497 1.0000000 #>  #> $intercepts #>           new1        new2      new3 #> new1   0.00000   0.2557471 0.1846321 #> new2  62.03131   0.0000000 0.2318999 #> new3 -36.94346 -87.1236135 0.0000000 #>  #> $slopes #>          new1      new2      new3 #> new1 1.000000 -6.188395  7.677857 #> new2 1.054369  1.000000 69.003356 #> new3 5.065856  1.543350  1.000000 #>  #> $rsquared #>           [,1]      [,2]      [,3] #> [1,] 1.0000000 0.2696518 0.9353199 #> [2,] 0.2696518 1.0000000 0.3579026 #> [3,] 0.9353199 0.3579026 1.0000000 #>  get_stats(datasets::trees) #> $n #> [1] 31 #>  #> $means #>    Girth   Height   Volume  #> 13.24839 76.00000 30.17097  #>  #> $variances #>      Girth     Height     Volume  #>   9.847914  40.600000 270.202796  #>  #> $correlation #>            Girth    Height    Volume #> Girth  1.0000000 0.5192801 0.9671194 #> Height 0.5192801 1.0000000 0.5982497 #> Volume 0.9671194 0.5982497 1.0000000 #>  #> $intercepts #>            Girth      Height    Volume #> Girth    0.00000   0.2557471 0.1846321 #> Height  62.03131   0.0000000 0.2318999 #> Volume -36.94346 -87.1236135 0.0000000 #>  #> $slopes #>           Girth    Height    Volume #> Girth  1.000000 -6.188395  7.677857 #> Height 1.054369  1.000000 69.003356 #> Volume 5.065856  1.543350  1.000000 #>  #> $rsquared #>           [,1]      [,2]      [,3] #> [1,] 1.0000000 0.2696518 0.9353199 #> [2,] 0.2696518 1.0000000 0.3579026 #> [3,] 0.9353199 0.3579026 1.0000000 #>

what: Animation of several mimicking datasets — mimic_gif
title: Animation of several mimicking datasets — mimic_gif
text: Create animation show datasets mimic target dataset x2.

title: Animation of several mimicking datasets — mimic_gif
code: mimic_gif(   x,   x2,   idempotent = TRUE,   theme_name = "classic",   ease = "cubic-in-out",   transition_length = 3,   state_length = 1,   wrap = TRUE )

title: Animation of several mimicking datasets — mimic_gif
text: x list input datasets.  one must suitable argument x mimic. x2 suitable argument x2 mimic. idempotent logical vector provides argument names mimic dataset.  necessary, rep_len used replicate argument length length(x). theme_name character scalar used set ggtheme. One "grey", "gray", "bw", "linedraw", "light", "dark", "minimal", "classic", "void" "test". ease character scalar passed ease_aes control points move transitioning one dataset next. transition_length, state_length, wrap Arguments passed transition_states.

title: Animation of several mimicking datasets — mimic_gif
text: object class c("gganim", "gg", "ggplot") additional attribute new_data data frame 3 variables, x, y dataset containing datasets output mimc. returned object may displayed using typing name, e.g., anim saved GIF file using anim_save, e.g., gganimate::anim_save("anscombe.gif", anim).

title: Animation of several mimicking datasets — mimic_gif
text: function work packages ggplot2 gganimate must installed.

title: Animation of several mimicking datasets — mimic_gif
code: # Create 8 datasets that mimic Anscombe's first dataset x <- list(input1, input2, input3, input4, input5, input6, input7, input8) anim <- mimic_gif(x, anscombe1)

title: Create a list of summary statistics — set_stats
code: # Uncorrelated with zero means and unit variances set_stats() #> $means #> [1] 0 0 #>  #> $variances #> [1] 1 1 #>  #> $correlation #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]    1    0 #> [2,]    0    1 #>  # Sample correlation = 0.9 set_stats(correlation = matrix(c(1, 0.9, 0.9, 1), 2, 2)) #> $means #> [1] 0 0 #>  #> $variances #> [1] 1 1 #>  #> $correlation #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]  1.0  0.9 #> [2,]  0.9  1.0 #>

title: anscombiser 1.1.0
text: CRAN release: 2022-10-02

title: anscombiser 1.1.0
text: functions anscombise mimic new argument idempotent. See documentation functions details. default setting idempotent = TRUE version 1.0.0 anscombiser equates idempotent = FALSE. New functions anscombise_gif mimic_gif produce animations plots datasets summary statistics. Eight simple datasets can used input anscombise create Anscombe-like datasets provided.

title: anscombiser 1.1.0
text: Corrected description class returned object documentation anscombise mimic. Minor cosmetic improvements package manual. Activated 3rd edition testthat package.
